definitions: Tiny air sacs in the lungs where gas exchange occurs between air and blood.
Microscopic lung structures that provide a large surface area for O2–CO2 diffusion.
Terminal lung sacs where oxygen enters pulmonary capillaries and CO2 leaves blood.
The primary site of external respiration, exchanging gases between ventilation and perfusion.
Air-filled sacs whose thin walls enable rapid diffusion of respiratory gases.
Lung units at the end of alveolar ducts where gas transfer to blood occurs.
Structures lined by a thin respiratory membrane to facilitate gas exchange.
The functional gas-exchange spaces where alveolar PO2/PCO2 gradients drive diffusion.
Portion of the respiratory system where air does not participate in gas exchange.
The volume of air in conducting airways (nose → bronchi) that never reaches alveoli.
Non-exchanging airway space where ventilation moves air but diffusion with blood does not occur.
Airway volume that is ventilated but lacks alveoli, so no O2/CO2 transfer happens there.
The dead space of the conducting passages, excluding gas-exchange regions.
Respiratory tract volume that fills first during inspiration and empties first during expiration.
The part of each breath that stays in the conducting airways and does not oxygenate blood.
Conducting airway volume that contributes to ventilation but not to alveolar gas exchange.
The difference in oxygen content between arterial and venous blood (a–vO₂ difference).
A measure of how much O2 is extracted by tissues from the blood.
The arterial O2 content minus venous O2 content, reflecting peripheral oxygen utilization.
An indicator of oxygen extraction: how much oxygen disappears from blood as it passes tissues.
A variable that widens when working muscles take more O2 from each unit of blood.
The O2 content drop from arteries to veins, representing tissue uptake of oxygen.
A measure of peripheral (muscle) oxygen extraction used in the Fick relationship.
Difference between CaO2 and CvO2 that reflects how much oxygen tissues remove.
Methods used to increase red blood cell mass to enhance oxygen delivery.
Practices that raise hemoglobin/RBC concentration to improve aerobic performance capacity.
Artificially increasing oxygen-carrying capacity through added RBCs or similar interventions.
Increasing total red cell volume to boost VO2max potential and endurance performance.
Strategies that elevate hematocrit to improve oxygen transport (often prohibited).
Performance enhancement by augmenting red blood cell count to deliver more O2 to muscles.
Manipulations that increase blood’s oxygen-carrying capacity by raising RBC mass.
Methods (e.g., transfusion-based) intended to improve endurance by elevating hemoglobin.
An abnormally slow resting heart rate, common in endurance-trained athletes.
A low resting HR often reflecting high parasympathetic tone and/or increased stroke volume.
A resting heart rate below typical norms (often <60 bpm) depending on context and symptoms.
Slow heart rhythm at rest; may be normal in well-trained individuals.
A reduced resting pulse rate that can occur with aerobic training adaptations.
A slower-than-average heart rate, sometimes indicating cardiovascular efficiency in athletes.
A low resting HR caused by pacemaker rate reduction and increased vagal influence.
A resting HR reduction often seen after endurance training due to autonomic adaptations.
The volume of blood pumped by the heart per minute (heart rate × stroke volume).
A measure of total blood flow from the heart each minute, equal to HR times SV.
The heart’s pumping rate expressed as liters per minute of blood ejected.
Total circulatory flow per minute produced by ventricular ejection.
A key determinant of oxygen delivery that rises with increased heart rate and stroke volume.
Blood flow generated by the heart per unit time, typically reported in L/min.
The product of beats per minute and blood ejected per beat.
Minute-by-minute blood volume output from the heart (CO = HR × SV).
The partial or complete loss of training-induced physiological adaptations.
A decline in fitness and performance when training volume/intensity is reduced or stopped.
Reversal or reduction of training gains due to insufficient stimulus.
Loss of cardiovascular, metabolic, and neuromuscular adaptations after inactivity.
A regression of performance capacities when overload is removed.
The decay of conditioning effects following decreased training frequency or load.
A reduction in exercise-induced improvements caused by reduced training exposure.
Adaptation loss that occurs when training stress drops below maintenance thresholds.
The relaxation phase of the cardiac cycle during ventricular filling.
The period when ventricles relax and fill with blood before contraction.
Cardiac cycle phase characterized by low ventricular pressure and chamber filling.
The heart’s filling phase, occurring between systolic contractions.
Relaxation of the myocardium allowing blood to enter the ventricles.
The phase after systole when the ventricles refill from venous return.
Ventricular filling period when AV valves are open (most of the time).
The cardiac relaxation interval during which end-diastolic volume is established.
Arterial pressure during ventricular relaxation.
The lower blood pressure value, reflecting arterial pressure between heartbeats.
Pressure in arteries when the ventricles are in diastole and not ejecting blood.
Minimum arterial pressure during the cardiac cycle, influenced by vascular resistance.
Arterial pressure during ventricular filling and relaxation phase.
The pressure maintained in arteries when the heart is resting between contractions.
Blood pressure measurement representing arterial recoil/resistance when the heart relaxes.
The baseline arterial pressure when the ventricle is not actively pumping.
Passive movement of molecules from areas of higher to lower concentration.
Net movement down a concentration or partial pressure gradient due to random motion.
Molecular movement from high to low concentration without energy input.
Gas transfer across membranes driven by pressure gradients (e.g., O2/CO2 in lungs).
A passive transport process determined by gradient magnitude and membrane properties.
Spontaneous spread of molecules from regions of greater to lesser concentration.
Movement of gases in respiration driven by differences in partial pressure.
Passive transport mechanism underlying O2 and CO2 exchange in alveoli and tissues.
Heart rate multiplied by systolic blood pressure; an index of myocardial workload.
A cardiac work estimate calculated as HR × systolic BP.
A proxy for myocardial oxygen demand based on heart rate and systolic pressure.
An index of how hard the heart is working during exercise: HR times SBP.
A workload marker often used in clinical/exercise settings to estimate cardiac strain.
A measure reflecting cardiac effort combining pumping frequency and arterial pressure.
A calculated indicator of myocardial stress: the product of HR and SBP.
An approximate indicator of cardiac oxygen consumption derived from HR and systolic BP.
The percentage of end-diastolic volume ejected from the ventricle per beat.
Fraction of ventricular filling volume pumped out during systole (SV/EDV).
A measure of pumping effectiveness: how much of EDV is expelled each contraction.
The proportion of blood in the ventricle that is ejected with each heartbeat.
A functional index of ventricular systolic performance.
Percent of ventricular volume expelled per beat, commonly used clinically for heart function.
A ratio describing how completely the ventricle empties relative to its filled volume.
The percentage of EDV expelled during systole, reflecting systolic function.
The volume of blood in the ventricle at the end of diastole.
The filled ventricular volume just before systole begins.
The amount of blood in a ventricle after it finishes filling.
Ventricular preload volume immediately prior to contraction.
The maximum ventricular volume in the cardiac cycle, established during diastole.
Blood volume in the ventricle right before the heart ejects blood.
The ventricular filling volume that contributes to stroke volume via Frank-Starling effects.
Ventricular volume at the end of filling, serving as the starting point for ejection.
A hormone that stimulates red blood cell production.
A hormone (primarily from kidneys) that promotes erythropoiesis in bone marrow.
The key regulator hormone that increases RBC formation in response to hypoxia.
A signaling hormone that boosts hemoglobin-carrying capacity by increasing RBC synthesis.
A hormone that stimulates maturation and production of erythrocytes.
The endocrine signal that raises red cell mass when oxygen availability is low.
A hormone that increases oxygen-carrying capacity by promoting RBC generation.
A hypoxia-responsive hormone driving bone marrow to make more red blood cells.
An equation describing oxygen consumption as cardiac output multiplied by a–vO₂ difference.
A relationship stating VO2 depends on blood flow (Q) and tissue oxygen extraction.
VO2 equals cardiac output times the arteriovenous O2 difference.
A principle linking oxygen uptake to central delivery and peripheral extraction factors.
A formula showing VO2 rises with increased CO and/or increased a–vO2 difference.
A model for oxygen consumption based on circulation and O2 content differences.
The equation that partitions VO2 into central (Q) and peripheral (extraction) components.
A foundational exercise physiology relationship: VO2 = HR×SV × (CaO2−CvO2).
The relationship between ventricular filling and force of contraction.
Greater end-diastolic filling leads to stronger contraction and increased stroke volume.
A mechanism where increased preload increases myocardial stretch and enhances force output.
The heart’s intrinsic ability to pump more when it fills more.
The preload–stroke volume relationship mediated by myocardial fiber stretch.
A principle stating SV increases when EDV increases (within physiological limits).
Increased venous return raises EDV and thus increases contractile force and SV.
The rule that stretching cardiac muscle fibers more (via filling) increases contraction strength.
Short-term training overload followed by performance supercompensation.
A planned overload phase causing temporary fatigue and then improved performance after recovery.
Brief overreaching that resolves with rest and leads to rebound gains.
A productive training strategy: short performance dip, then higher peak after taper.
A short-term stress > recovery state that results in positive adaptation after restoration.
A purposeful overload block that yields improved fitness once fatigue dissipates.
Short-duration overreaching that improves performance after sufficient recovery.
An overload period intended to generate supercompensation rather than long-term decline.
The number of heart beats per minute.
A measure of cardiac cycle frequency expressed in beats per minute (bpm).
The rate of cardiac contractions per minute.
How many times the heart beats each minute at rest or during exercise.
A central cardiovascular variable influencing cardiac output (CO = HR × SV).
The heartbeat frequency, commonly used to gauge exercise intensity.
The number of ventricular contractions per minute (typically inferred from pulse).
A time-based measure of cardiac rhythm frequency (bpm).
Breathing oxygen-enriched air.
Inhaling air with a higher-than-normal fraction of oxygen (FiO2).
Ventilating with elevated oxygen concentration to increase arterial oxygenation.
Breathing supplemental oxygen above ambient levels.
Use of enriched O2 inhalation to raise inspired oxygen partial pressure.
Breathing with increased oxygen content to enhance oxygen availability to the body.
Inspiration of air with a greater oxygen percentage than room air (~21%).
Oxygen-supplemented breathing intended to elevate oxygen delivery or saturation.
Ventilation exceeding metabolic demand.
Breathing more than necessary for CO2 production, often lowering arterial CO2.
Excessive alveolar ventilation relative to metabolic requirements.
A ventilation state that can reduce CO2 and raise blood pH (respiratory alkalosis).
Increased breathing rate/depth beyond what is required to match metabolism.
Over-breathing that expels CO2 faster than it is produced.
Ventilatory output that surpasses what is needed to maintain CO2 balance.
Breathing disproportionately high relative to oxygen uptake and CO2 production.
The highest heart rate attainable during maximal exercise.
An individual’s peak heart rate reached under maximal effort conditions.
Maximum beats per minute achievable during all-out exercise.
The upper limit of heart rate response to increasing exercise intensity.
Peak heart rate reached during maximal graded exercise testing.
The highest HR produced when effort is maximal and fatigue stops further increase.
An upper bound heart rate value used to scale intensity zones (imperfectly).
The maximum cardiac frequency the body can achieve during maximal exertion.
The highest rate at which oxygen can be consumed during exercise (VO₂max).
Maximal aerobic power: peak oxygen consumption during exhaustive exercise.
The maximal capacity to take in, transport, and use oxygen during intense activity.
A key marker of cardiorespiratory fitness measured as peak VO2.
The upper limit of aerobic ATP production capacity expressed via oxygen consumption.
Peak rate of oxygen utilization during maximal effort, often in ml·kg⁻¹·min⁻¹.
Maximum oxygen uptake reflecting central delivery and peripheral extraction limits.
The highest measurable VO2 during maximal graded exercise.
The average arterial pressure throughout the cardiac cycle.
A weighted average blood pressure reflecting overall perfusion pressure.
An estimate of average driving pressure for blood flow to tissues.
Average arterial pressure accounting for longer diastole than systole.
A pressure value used to approximate tissue perfusion status.
A summary measure of arterial pressure across one heartbeat.
The average effective pressure pushing blood through systemic circulation.
An average BP measure often estimated from SBP and DBP (approximation).
A unit representing resting metabolic rate (~3.5 ml O₂·kg⁻¹·min⁻¹).
A standard unit for estimating energy cost of activities relative to rest.
A multiple of resting oxygen consumption used to describe exercise intensity.
A unit where 1 MET approximates resting VO2 and higher METs reflect greater demand.
A practical intensity unit expressing activity cost as times-resting metabolism.
A measure of energy expenditure scaling activity demand to resting oxygen uptake.
A standardized intensity unit used in exercise prescription and compendiums.
A resting-metabolism reference unit for comparing workloads and activity energy cost.
The volume of air breathed per minute (tidal volume × breathing frequency).
Total air moved in or out of the lungs each minute.
Ventilatory flow per minute calculated as VT times breathing rate.
The amount of ventilation per minute used to support gas exchange.
A respiratory variable representing total ventilation output each minute.
Total inhaled/exhaled air volume per minute, rising with exercise intensity.
The combined effect of breath size and breath frequency on ventilation per minute.
Ventilation per minute, determined by tidal volume and respiratory rate.
Cell organelles responsible for aerobic energy production.
The primary site of oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic ATP synthesis.
Organelles where the Krebs cycle and electron transport chain operate.
Cellular structures that generate ATP using oxygen-dependent pathways.
The ‘powerhouses’ where aerobic metabolism converts fuels into ATP.
Organelles that house enzymes for fat oxidation and aerobic carbohydrate metabolism.
Structures that produce ATP via electron transport and chemiosmosis.
Subcellular sites where oxygen is used to generate ATP efficiently.
An oxygen-binding protein in muscle that facilitates oxygen transport within fibers.
A muscle protein that stores and shuttles oxygen to mitochondria.
An intracellular oxygen carrier that helps buffer and deliver O2 in muscle cells.
A heme-containing protein in muscle that binds O2 more readily than hemoglobin.
A protein that assists oxygen diffusion inside muscle fibers during exercise.
A muscle oxygen reservoir that supports aerobic metabolism, especially at onset or high demand.
An O2-binding molecule that improves oxygen availability near mitochondria.
A muscle-cell oxygen carrier aiding intramuscular oxygen transfer and storage.
Overreaching leading to prolonged performance decrements without supercompensation.
A maladaptive overreaching state where performance does not rebound quickly with rest.
Excess training stress causing longer-lasting underperformance without a positive rebound.
An overload condition requiring extended recovery, without subsequent performance gain.
A training-stress imbalance that produces sustained fatigue and reduced performance.
Overreaching that lasts too long or is too severe to produce beneficial supercompensation.
A negative overreaching state that persists for weeks rather than days.
A state between functional overreaching and overtraining syndrome marked by prolonged decline.
A short-term imbalance between training stress and recovery.
A temporary overload state that suppresses performance due to accumulated fatigue.
A period of training stress exceeding recovery capacity, often intentionally.
Short-term fatigue accumulation that may be functional or nonfunctional.
A spike in training load that transiently reduces performance until recovery occurs.
An overload phase that can lead to adaptation if followed by adequate rest.
A short-duration excess of training stress over recovery resources.
A training load imbalance producing temporary underperformance.
Chronic maladaptive training state with prolonged performance decline.
A long-term condition where excessive training with insufficient recovery impairs performance.
Sustained underperformance due to training stress exceeding adaptive capacity over time.
A maladaptation characterized by persistent fatigue and reduced performance beyond normal recovery.
A chronic training-related decline often accompanied by mood and physiological disturbances.
A long-duration breakdown in recovery-adaptation balance due to repeated overload.
Persistent performance decrement caused by cumulative training stress and inadequate restoration.
A chronic maladaptive outcome of excessive training load without sufficient recovery.
A severe form of overtraining characterized by long-term performance decrements.
A chronic syndrome of persistent fatigue and underperformance requiring weeks to months to recover.
A long-lasting maladaptive training condition affecting multiple physiological systems.
A syndrome involving sustained performance decline not resolved by short rest periods.
A chronic training-related disorder with prolonged recovery needs and systemic dysregulation.
The most serious maladaptation on the overtraining continuum, beyond NFOR.
A long-term underperformance state often paired with mood/sleep/immune disruptions.
A chronic syndrome of performance decline due to prolonged training stress and inadequate recovery.
The amount of oxygen consumed by the body (VO₂).
Rate of oxygen utilization by the body during rest or exercise.
Oxygen consumption reflecting aerobic metabolic rate.
The volume of O2 used per unit time, often expressed in L/min or ml·kg⁻¹·min⁻¹.
A measure of aerobic energy turnover based on oxygen usage.
The amount of oxygen extracted and used by tissues from inspired air.
An index of metabolic demand and aerobic ATP production.
The body’s oxygen consumption rate during activity.
Ventilated lung areas that are not perfused with blood.
Air spaces where ventilation occurs but effective gas exchange does not due to poor perfusion.
The sum of anatomical dead space plus alveoli that are ventilated but underperfused.
Non-exchanging ventilated volume caused by ventilation–perfusion mismatch.
Dead space that includes conducting airways and nonperfused (or poorly perfused) alveoli.
Ventilation that does not contribute to gas exchange because blood flow is absent or inadequate.
Portion of each breath that fails to exchange gases due to lack of perfusion.
Ventilated but non-exchanging lung volume arising from inadequate pulmonary capillary blood flow.
Heart rate multiplied by systolic blood pressure; indicator of cardiac work.
An index of myocardial workload calculated as HR × SBP.
A proxy measure for myocardial oxygen demand based on HR and systolic pressure.
A cardiac strain estimate combining how often the heart beats and the pressure it pumps against.
A workload metric frequently used to gauge cardiac effort during exercise testing.
An indicator of heart work and oxygen demand derived from HR and SBP.
A calculated cardiac load index reflecting both rate and pressure demands.
A simple estimate of myocardial stress: heart rate times systolic blood pressure.
The volume of blood ejected by the ventricle with each beat.
Blood pumped per heartbeat from one ventricle.
Amount of blood expelled during systole per contraction.
The difference between end-diastolic volume and end-systolic volume (SV = EDV − ESV).
A key contributor to cardiac output alongside heart rate.
Volume ejected per beat, influenced by preload, contractility, and afterload.
The per-beat output of the heart’s ventricle.
Blood volume pumped out of the ventricle during each contraction.
The contraction phase of the cardiac cycle.
The period when ventricles generate pressure and eject blood.
Cardiac phase in which the heart pumps blood into the arteries.
Ventricular contraction interval producing stroke volume.
The ejection phase of the heartbeat when ventricular pressure rises.
The cardiac contraction period that drives blood flow out of the ventricles.
Phase of the cardiac cycle associated with ventricular depolarization and ejection.
The portion of the cycle when the ventricles contract to propel blood forward.
Arterial pressure during ventricular contraction.
The higher blood pressure value reflecting peak pressure during ejection.
Maximum arterial pressure reached during systole.
Pressure in arteries when the ventricle is actively pumping blood.
Peak pressure generated as blood is forced into the aorta and arteries.
The top number in a BP reading, representing pressure during ventricular ejection.
Arterial pressure at the moment of greatest ventricular force output.
Peak arterial pressure occurring during the contraction phase of the heartbeat.
A reduction in training volume prior to competition to enhance performance.
Planned training reduction to decrease fatigue while maintaining fitness.
A pre-competition strategy that lowers training load to peak performance.
A short phase where workload drops to allow supercompensation and readiness.
Reducing volume (and sometimes intensity) to improve performance and recovery status.
Training load reduction intended to sharpen performance and restore freshness.
A period of decreased training stress leading into competition for peak output.
A strategy to reduce accumulated fatigue and maximize performance capacity.
The volume of air inspired or expired with each breath.
Air volume moved per breath at rest or during exercise.
The amount of air entering/leaving the lungs with a single respiratory cycle.
Breath size: the per-breath air volume.
Volume exchanged in one normal inspiration/expiration.
A component of minute ventilation (VE = VT × breathing frequency).
The per-breath air volume that can increase with exercise intensity.
Air volume inhaled or exhaled during a single breath.
Narrowing of blood vessels to reduce blood flow.
Decreased vessel diameter caused by smooth muscle contraction in vessel walls.
A vascular response that increases resistance and reduces downstream blood flow.
Constriction of arterioles that raises peripheral resistance and alters distribution of blood.
Reduction in lumen size that can increase blood pressure and limit perfusion.
A response that decreases local blood supply by tightening vascular smooth muscle.
Decreased vessel radius leading to increased resistance to blood flow.
Vessel narrowing that reduces flow and can elevate arterial pressure.
Widening of blood vessels to increase blood flow.
Increased vessel diameter due to relaxation of vascular smooth muscle.
A vascular response that lowers resistance and increases downstream perfusion.
Expansion of arterioles that improves blood delivery to tissues.
Increased lumen size that reduces peripheral resistance and can lower blood pressure.
A response that increases local blood supply by relaxing vascular smooth muscle.
An increase in vessel radius that decreases resistance to blood flow.
Vessel widening that enhances flow and supports oxygen/nutrient delivery.
The flow of blood back to the heart.
The volume of blood returning to the right atrium per unit time.
Blood return from systemic circulation to the heart.
A key determinant of end-diastolic volume and thus stroke volume.
The amount of blood that returns via veins, influenced by muscle pump and respiration.
Return flow of blood to the heart that supports ventricular filling.
The venous blood flow back to the heart that affects preload.
Blood returning through the venous system to fill the heart before ejection.
The ratio of ventilation to oxygen uptake or carbon dioxide output.
A measure of how much ventilation is required per unit of O2 consumed (VE/VO2) or CO2 produced (VE/VCO2).
An index of ventilatory efficiency during exercise testing.
A respiratory efficiency metric expressing ventilation relative to metabolic gas exchange.
A ratio used to evaluate ventilatory response and detect ventilatory thresholds.
The amount of air ventilated for a given level of oxygen uptake or carbon dioxide production.
A measure where higher values can indicate less efficient ventilation.
Ventilation divided by VO2 or VCO2, reflecting how hard you must breathe for metabolic demand.
